channel.title: The Sydney Morning Herald World Headlines
channel.description: The top World headlines from The Sydney Morning Herald. For all the news, visit http://www.smh.com.au.

item.title: Cracks in Israel coalition over national service
item.description: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has disbanded the committee he ordered to devise a plan for universal military or national service.

item.title: Jehovah patients 'recover faster'
item.description: Jehovah's Witnesses, whose faith forbids them from blood transfusions, recover from heart surgery faster and with fewer complications than those who do get blood, in a study that may change thinking on current practice.

item.title: PNG cult killings disrupt elections
item.description: Voting in Papua New Guinea looks set to go into an unscheduled third week as polls in the violence-prone Highlands provinces will not be completed by Friday. In the eastern island group of Bougainville, election teams will not have a ship to take them to outlying atolls until early next week.

item.title: Timor fund chief makes light of $10.5bn account
item.description: "If I've got $600 million a year ... you'll partake in it," Olgario de Castro reassures his mates, his voice caught by a secret recorder as coffee cups clink in the background.

item.title: US spent $11bn - and the rest - to protect secrets last year
item.description: The US government spent more than $US11 billion to protect its secrets last year, double the cost of classification a decade ago - and that is only the part it will reveal.

item.title: 'I'm gay … and proud', says Cooper
item.description: LOS ANGELES: Anderson Cooper has made it official: he's gay.

item.title: Fears diplomacy is dead as reports of torture grow
item.description: AFTER a damning report on Syria's extensive network of underground detention centres that have been used to torture thousands during its 16-month-long uprising, there are renewed fears the conflict has slipped beyond diplomacy into a protracted ground war.

item.title: Netanyahu coalition at war over conscription
item.description: JERUSALEM: The Israeli Prime Minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has disbanded the committee he had charged with devising a plan for universal military or national service, a move that could lead to a coalition crisis and end the national unity government he formed two months ago.

item.title: Turkish plane attack was a mistake - Assad
item.description: ANKARA: The Syrian President, Bashar al-Assad, regretted that his country's defence forces shot down a Turkish fighter jet on June 22, he said in an interview with the Turkish newspaper Cumhuriyet which was published yesterday.

item.title: Atlantic sanctuary for whales scuttled
item.description: PANAMA CITY: Japan and its allies have shot down a Latin American-led proposal to create a sanctuary for whales in the southern Atlantic Ocean, reigniting international tensions over Tokyo's whaling.

item.title: Cult killings mar PNG election
item.description: PORT MORESBY: As Papua New Guinea struggles to complete its national elections, a spate of killings linked to a local men's cult fighting alleged sorcerers has disrupted polling in a swathe of remote jungle.

item.title: Europe joblessness at record high
item.description: MORE than one in 10 people in the eurozone are out of work, including nearly a quarter of Spaniards, pushing the currency bloc's unemployment rate to a record-high 11.1 per cent in May.

item.title: Jehovah's Witnesses recover best from surgery, despite refusing blood
item.description: NEW YORK: Jehovah's Witnesses, whose faith forbids them from blood transfusions, recover from heart surgery faster and with fewer complications than those who do get blood, a study has found.

item.title: Talk is cheap on East Timor's financial future
item.description: ''IF I'VE got $600 million a year … you'll partake in it,'' Olgario de Castro reassures his mates, his voice caught by a secret recorder as coffee cups clink in the background.

item.title: Scientists close in on 'God particle'
item.description: IN WHAT would be one of the most significant finds in a century, scientists are expected to announce the existence of a new particle tonight that could be the famed Higgs boson.

item.title: Settled petals: Australian models in hot demand in Paris
item.description: THE most eagerly awaited show at the Paris haute couture collections was festooned with flowers - and Australian fashion models.

item.title: 7-magnitude quake hits NZ's North Island
item.description: A large earthquake has rocked New Zealand's North Island on Tuesday night but no damage has been reported.

item.title: Ferrari designer Pininfarina dies aged 85
item.description: The Italian godfather of car design, Sergio Pininfarina, renowned for crafting sleek Ferrari cars, has died aged 85, Italian media reports.

item.title: Italy ship black box did not work: report
item.description: An Italian cruise ship which sank in January, causing the deaths of 32 people, wasn't equipped with a functioning black box, a report says.

item.title: Iraq attacks kill 36, wound 100
item.description: A truck bomb has killed 25 people at a crowded market in central Iraq.

item.title: Police target group behind boat disasters
item.description: Indonesian police say a 19-year-old Afghan national has admitted his role in two voyages that led to the deaths of almost 100 asylum seekers.

item.title: Smuggler behind fateful trip 'in Australian hands'
item.description: Australian Federal Police have confirmed they are working with Indonesian police to try to track people smugglers responsible for a boat that sank north of Christmas Island 12 days ago, with the loss of an estimated 90 lives.

item.title: Revealed: Syrian torture centres
item.description: Former detainees, torture victims and defectors reveal the torture secrets of the Assad regime.

item.title: Quest to find the Wild Man
item.description: For centuries, the villagers around the Shennongjia forest of China's central Hubei province, a forbidding 1,000 square mile reserve of high mountains and deep forests, have believed that the "Wild Man", or Yeren, lives among them.

item.title: The voice: 'Every one person you kill there is like taking 50 lives'
item.description: Forty-eight hours into the bloody assault on Mumbai in November 2008, smoke was billowing from the wreckage of the Taj Mahal hotel and commandos were flushing out the last gunmen holed up in the opulent landmark of India's financial capital.

item.title: Strengthen Syria observer mission: UN
item.description: The UN high commissioner for human rights has called on the Security Council to strengthen the suspended UN observer mission in Syria.

item.title: Scientists to reveal God particle findings
item.description: Scientists are poised to reveal the findings of an experiment that is searching for the so-called God particle.

item.title: US grounds fire-fighting C-130 aircraft
item.description: The US military has suspended flights for C-130 transport planes equipped to fight wild fires after one aircraft crashed in South Dakota.

item.title: At least 22 dead after US storms cut power
item.description: The death toll from weekend summer storms in the eastern United States has risen to 22.

item.title: Court orders US protester's tweets
item.description: A US judge has ordered Twitter to hand over almost three months' worth of an Occupy Wall Street protester's tweets.

item.title: Aussies can still win ODI series: Bailey
item.description: Down 2-0 and having been thoroughly outplayed in the opening fixtures, Australia still feel they can win the ODI series against England.

item.title: Dolled-up Sindy seeking former glory
item.description: Sindy is planning a makeover to once again compete with her bigger-busted American doppelganger - Barbie.

item.title: Guest workers to prop up North Korean regime
item.description: China is inviting tens of thousands of North Korean guest workers into the country in a deal that will provide a cash infusion to prop up the teetering Stalinist regime.

item.title: Jellyfish warning websites
item.description: FRANCE

item.title: Kim Jong-il ordered 'massive' nuclear build-up
item.description: THE late North Korean leader Kim Jong-il ordered scientists to produce ''a massive amount'' of uranium bombs, according to regime documents, reports in Japan say.

item.title: Libyan protesters storm poll offices
item.description: With Libya's landmark elections for a constituent assembly only days away, armed protesters have ransacked the offices of the national election commission in the eastern cities of Benghazi and Tobruk.

item.title: On cusp of sovereignty
item.description: Kosovo was due to become a fully sovereign state overnight as the International Steering Group back their bags.

item.title: Softer view on Pius XII
item.description: Israel's national holocaust memorial has toned down its account of Pope Pius XII's conduct towards the massacre of Jews during World War II.

item.title: Somare seeks to deliver lesson to PNG 'usurpers'
item.description: The former prime minister vows never to work with his rivals, Hamish McDonald reports from Wewak.

item.title: Barclays chairman quits over rates rort
item.description: LONDON: The interest rate rigging scandal has claimed its first scalp among the senior management of Barclays with the resignation of the bank's chairman, Marcus Agius. He is expected to apologise for the scandal.

item.title: China opens doors to North Korean workers
item.description: SEOUL: China is inviting tens of thousands of North Korean guest workers into the country in a deal that will provide a cash infusion to help prop up a teetering regime with little more to export than the drudgery of a desperately poor population.

item.title: Decision to restart nuclear reactor sparks street protests in Japan
item.description: TOKYO: Electricity will start being generated tomorrow from a nuclear reactor at the Ohi plant north-east of Osaka, ending a two-month period when all the country's 50 reactors were offline for safety checks following the Fukushima disaster.

item.title: Somare to take insult and injury back to Parliament
item.description: WEWAK: Michael Somare, Papua New Guinea's version of ''Lazarus with a triple bypass'', is looking forward to returning to Parliament and dishing it back to the political rivals who kicked him out last year.

item.title: Title plan for partners of gay knights
item.description: LONDON: The partners of gay knights and peers could be given titles like those for wives of heterosexual men under plans before the British Parliament.

item.title: Holocaust museum softens its criticism of Pope's war actions
item.description: JERUSALEM: Israel's Holocaust museum and memorial, Yad Vashem, has changed the wording of an exhibit on Pope Pius XII's actions during World War II to soften its criticism of the Pope over a subject that has long divided Jews and the Vatican.

item.title: Millions swelter in wake of savage storms
item.description: WASHINGTON: More than 3 million people in the eastern United States endured a second day of near 40-degree temperatures without electricity after storms ripped through the region. The death toll reached 17.

item.title: Papa calls the shots at Camp Romney
item.description: This annual family holiday is a compulsory - and competitive - affair, write Raf Sanchez and Philip Rucker.

item.title: Pena Nieto claims election win and new era for Mexico
item.description: MEXICO CITY: Enrique Pena Nieto, a dynamic, crowd-pleasing politician and the new face of a once-corrupt political party, has been elected president of Mexico by a wide margin, according to exit polls by the country's major media outlets.

item.title: Regional rivalries flare in Libya as elections spark protests
item.description: BENGHAZI: Supporters of a federal system in Libya have ransacked offices of the electoral commission to protest against this weekend's elections.

item.title: Scientology creepy, maybe evil, says Murdoch
item.description: ITS devotees may include some of Hollywood's biggest box office earners. But when Scientology was raised as a possible cause for the break-up of Tom Cruise and Katie Holmes, Rupert Murdoch could not resist commenting.

item.title: Aussie teen wonders what may have been
item.description: Australian teenage tennis ace Luke Saville has made an impressive start to his junior Wimbledon title defence but still wonders what might have been.

item.title: McEwen gives Tour cycling team an edge
item.description: Robbie McEwen is using his years of experience and attention to detail to help GreenEDGE as their Tour de France sprint coach.

item.title: Seven killed in Afghan university blast
item.description: Seven people are dead and 23 injured after a suicide car bombing at the gate of a university in southern Afghanistan.

item.title: Djokovic hails Federer's latest feat
item.description: World No.1 Novak Djokovic has opted to marvel at Roger Federer's crazy grand slam quarter-final streak than get caught up in Wimbledon's scheduling row.

item.title: Australian lawyer detained in Libya goes free
item.description: Libya releases Australian lawyer Melinda Taylor and three of her ICC colleagues.

item.title: Vanquished Sharapova to hit back
item.description: Maria Sharapova is in danger of losing her world No.1 ranking after suffering a fourth-round Wimbledon loss to German Sabine Lisicki.

item.title: Serena sneaks into Wimbledon quarters
item.description: Four-times champion Serena Williams has survived a three-set scare to reach the Wimbledon quarter-finals for the 10th time.

item.title: Russia to hold talks with Syria opposition
item.description: Russia will hold talks with two Syrian opposition groups and with UN envoy Kofi Annan later this month.

item.title: Man arrested over deadly voyage
item.description: A man suspected of organising the asylum-seeker boat that sank en route to Australia last month, killing about 90 people, has been arrested.

item.title: Taylor awaits release from Libyan custody
item.description: Australian lawyer Melinda Taylor looks set to be released from Libyan custody, almost a month after being detained.

item.title: Seven deaths blamed on PNG cargo cult
item.description: Police in Papua New Guinea say seven people have reportedly died after a cargo cult attacked villagers in the remote Bogia area over the weekend.

item.title: Blackmarket organ trade spreads among Europe's poor
item.description: Facing grinding poverty and chronic joblessness, some Europeans are seeking to sell body parts to survive.

item.title: Canadian cops think they found human head
item.description: Canadian police have found what appears to be a human head in a park in Montreal and are investigating whether it is the missing head of a Chinese student.

item.title: Faulty PNG electoral roll blamed on fraud
item.description: PNG's electoral commissioner has defended his agency's handling of the 2012 elections, saying the rolls had been tampered with after they left his hands.

item.title: 'We're going to destroy everything before we apply Sharia in this city'
item.description: Islamist rebels say they will continue to destroy historic sites in Timbuktu before they implement strict Sharia law, as Mali's government compared the destruction to "war crimes".

item.title: Woods wins PGA's National, passes Nicklaus
item.description: Tiger Woods has held off Bo Van Pelt to record a two-shot win at the USPGA AT&T National in Bethesda, Maryland.

item.title: Magic Monday at Wimbledon
item.description: The world's premier tennis players are set for 16 fourth-round men's and women's matches on Magic Monday at Wimbledon.

item.title: Entrance to Timbuktu mosque destroyed
item.description: Islamist militants in Mali have attacked one of the most famous mosques in the historic city of Timbuktu with the ICC calling it a "war crime".

item.title: Windies dominate NZ in second T20
item.description: New Zealand delivered an improved bowling effort, but couldn't match it with the bat, slumping to a 61-run T20 loss to the West Indies in Florida.

item.title: Protests mark restart of Japan nuclear reactor
item.description: Dozens of protesters have shouted and danced at the gate of the first nuclear power plant to restart since Japan shut down all of its reactors for safety checks following the Fukushima disaster.

item.title: Residents tour 350 burnt US homes
item.description: People who fled Colorado's worst fire have visited the most devastated neighbourhood and many found their homes were among the nearly 350 burned.

item.title: Rio de Janeiro becomes world heritage site
item.description: UNESCO has declared Rio de Janeiro a world heritage site, recognising the unique way its natural setting blends with the urban landscape.

item.title: Spain crushes Italy 4-0 in Euro 2012 final
item.description: A 4-0 thumping of Italy has given Spain an historical consecutive European football championship and third major tournament win.

item.title: Crisis talks produce little hope for peace in Syria
item.description: World powers fail to reach a consensus on calling for the removal of Syria's President Bashar al-Assad from power.

item.title: French delicacy banned
item.description: Californian foie gras fans stuffed themselves at last suppers over the weekend before a ban on the delicacy finally comes into force after years of wrangling.

item.title: Israel marks death of 'giant' Yitzhak Shamir
item.description: Israel's second-longest serving prime minister, Yitzhak Shamir, has died aged 96.

item.title: Millions swelter in US as killer storms strike
item.description: Violent storms have pummelled the eastern US, killing at least 13 people and leaving 3 million without power during a heat wave.

item.title: New leader sworn in
item.description: Leung Chun-ying vowed to boost public housing and build a 'more equitable society' as he was sworn in.

item.title: PNG poll tension erupts into killing
item.description: Several people reportedly hacked to death in an ambush near a polling station as Papua New Guinea lurches into the second week of national elections.

item.title: Rodney King buried
item.description: Rodney King, whose beating by police in 1992 sparked one of the worst urban riots in US history, has been laid to rest.

item.title: Suu Kyi to delay debut
item.description: Aung San Suu Kyi asks to postpone her scheduled debut in Parliament this week due to exhaustion from her whirlwind European tour.

item.title: Timbuktu's tombs ruined by militants
item.description: UNESCO watches in horror as Mali Islamic fundamentalists ravage fabled Timbuktu shrines it had listed as endangered sites just days before.

item.title: Winds of change as Mexicans vote
item.description: After 12 years, voters seem ready to bring back to power the party that dominated Mexico for most of the past century.

item.title: Deaths and violence as polls turn ugly in PNG
item.description: WEWAK: Three to six people are reported to have been hacked to death with bush-style parang knives in an ambush near a polling station as Papua New Guinea lurches into the second week of its troubled national elections.

item.title: Mafia fears could force President out of Mexico
item.description: MEXICO CITY: President Felipe Calderon has been telling guests that he and his family are likely to leave Mexico after his term expires in December. It will be too dangerous to remain, he warns in private conversation, because powerful drug mafias might come after him.

item.title: Summer storms kill 13, leave millions without power
item.description: WASHINGTON: Millions are sweltering in the aftermath of violent storms that pummelled the eastern United States, killing at least 13 people and leaving three million without power during a heatwave.

item.title: Wang resigns, signals trial
item.description: BEIJING: Wang Lijun, the former Chongqing police chief who revealed the involvement of Gu Kailai in the alleged murder of the British businessman Neil Heywood, has been forced to resign as a member of China's parliament, paving the way for him to be put on trial.

item.title: Cameron questions Britain's EU future
item.description: LONDON: The British Prime Minister, David Cameron, has opened the door to an historical referendum on the country's relationship with the European Union, declaring that voters need a ''real choice''.

item.title: Death of Shamir: Israeli statesman, militant and spy
item.description: THE man the British Foreign Office once described as ''among the most fanatical terrorist leaders'', who went on to become a senior Mossad spy and Israel's second-longest serving prime minister, Yitzhak Shamir, has died aged 96.

item.title: Hollande goes into bat for printed word
item.description: FRANCOIS HOLLANDE, who was once photographed engrossed in French History for Dummies, will find that his holiday reading is scrutinised this northern summer. But if he is like the general French population, he is more likely to be packing paperbacks than a digital reader. Ebooks in France have been slow to catch on, as readers overwhelmingly prefer the printed page.

item.title: Islamists attack Timbuktu's world heritage site shrines
item.description: ST PETERSBURG: Mali Islamic fundamentalists have ravaged fabled Timbuktu shrines for a second day, ignoring pleas by the UN cultural body UNESCO to stop the ''wanton destruction''.

item.title: Mursi proclaims 'a message of peace' for Egypt
item.description: CAIRO: The inauguration of Egypt's first democratically elected President signals a new stage in an ever murkier struggle to define the future of the nation after six decades of military-backed autocracy.

item.title: Transition plan for Syria but still no unity on Assad
item.description: WORLD leaders have agreed to push the Syrian government and opposition forces to begin negotiations towards a transitional government but failed to specify whether President Bashar al-Assad must be excluded.

item.title: Chamberlain's new quest for justice
item.description: MICHAEL CHAMBERLAIN, whose book, Heart of Stone, a comprehensive account of his case, is published today, is preparing for a possible campaign to have a national inquiry into the administration of justice in Australia.

item.title: Heat rises over record sea ice melt in Arctic
item.description: SEA ice in the Arctic was melting at a record pace last month, according to the US National Snow and Ice Data Centre.

item.title: Fresh call on Assange 'espionage'
item.description: The head of the United States Senate's powerful intelligence oversight committee renews calls for Julian Assange to be prosecuted for espionage.

item.title: Nieto wins Mexican presidential election
item.description: Enrique Pena Nieto, the candidate of the party that governed Mexico for decades, has won a resounding victory in the country's presidential election.

item.title: Israel memorial softens view of WWII pope
item.description: A new panel at Israel's national holocaust memorial tones down the account of Pope Pius XII's conduct toward the massacre of Jews during World War II.

item.title: Tour's third stage worries O'Grady
item.description: Australian cyclist Stuart O'Grady says there are plenty of traps for riders in the third stage of the Tour de France.

item.title: 54 life sentences for Hamas leader
item.description: A senior Hamas leader has been handed 54 life sentences over a string of suicide bombings in Israel in the early 2000s.
